questions.text: What is the most common exotic timber grown in plantations in New Zealand?
questions.hint: Refer to page 13 of the booklet for the fast-growing softwood planted since the 1930s.

questions.text: Name one New Zealand native timber commonly used for high-quality furniture.
questions.hint: Look at pages 12–13. Consider warm golden or light brown timbers used in cabinetry.

questions.text: Name one imported timber suitable for decking or outdoor furniture.
questions.hint: Check page 14 for dense, durable hardwoods from Southeast Asia.

questions.text: Name one timber commonly used for woodturning.
questions.hint: Review native and swamp timbers on pages 12–13, especially those with fine grain.

questions.text: Describe the effects of moisture on MDF.
questions.hint: Look at the disadvantages of MDF in the Manufactured Boards section on page 18 – what happens when it gets wet?

questions.text: Name a lightweight expanded plastic used for insulation and buoyancy.
questions.hint: Check the Plastics (Thermoplastics) section on page 22 – white beady foam sheets used for packaging and insulation.

questions.text: Name a hard, transparent plastic that can be bulletproof and noise‑resistant.
questions.hint: This one goes beyond the booklet (which talks about glass on page 24) – think of the clear plastic used for riot shields and bus shelters.

questions.text: Name the plastic sheet used as a waterproof membrane under concrete slabs.
questions.hint: See the note about polythene being used as a damp‑proof membrane (DPM) in the Plastics section on page 22.

questions.text: Name a commonly used metal that can be easily joined by welding.
questions.hint: Check the first bullet list under Mild steel on page 20 – it says it is easily worked and welded.

questions.text: What are the 3 main materials that make up concrete?
questions.hint: Read the first paragraph under Concrete on page 25 – it lists the three ingredients mixed together.

questions.text: What is the function of a primer coat when painting?
questions.hint: Check the description of Primer in the Paint section on page 26 – it talks about adhesion and protection.

questions.text: Identify 3 methods commonly used to apply paint.
questions.hint: See the first paragraph under Surface finishes/ Paint on page 26 – three methods are listed there.

questions.text: Name 2 types of polishes and state an advantage over oil finishes.
questions.hint: Compare the Oil section on page 27 with the Polish section on page 28 – look at wax polish and French polish.

questions.text: Name 2 types of varnishes and state an advantage of each.
questions.hint: Read the Varnish section on page 27 – look for acrylic varnish and polyurethane and what each is good at.
